review_title: Overview of Pros and Cons working at IUPUI
pros: Really good health and retirement benefits and PTO--30 days per year; 35 days after working there for 5 years. Most people--staff and faculty are nice. They give $1,300 towards your HSA each year. They give 10 percent of your salary towards a 403B retirement plan for you with Fidelity. If you plan to study, you get a discount on tuition for you and family members.
cons: No 100 percent remote work options, even during COVID-19. Limited ability for advancement and increase in salary...overworking every year to only get a 0-2 percent salary increase each year. Limited options for advancement, even with a Master's degree and doing more than one job at a time to keep up with the fact that they won't hire (or take 3-6 months to a year or more) to hire for replacements of those who leave and/or retire.

pros:
The reason everyone I knew stayed as long as they did was the health benefits.

Parental leave after 1 year, a good amount of accrued PTO starting immediately.
cons:
It is very difficult to advance your career without getting a masters degree regardless of years of experience. The new "job framework" also pigeon-holes professionals so it is also hard to change roles between departments. 

Due to the pandemic, we went 3 years without a cost of living increase in pay. 

One wouldn't be so concerned with transferring if the department they worked for was appropriately managed by HR to handle the unusually high turnover rate due to an extremely toxic work environment. (Including wage theft, gender bias, race bias, chronic under-staffing, lack of communication of expectations, management sleeping through meetings, being asked to do clinical tasks you are not qualified to do, etc.)

review_title: Excellent work environment. Life-changing. Great management.
pros:
I have never felt more loved, supported, and valued by an employer. The Writing Center is more than a job-- it's a community, a whole new kind of education. "Diversity" is not just lip service here-- everything the writing center does pushes toward decolonial practice, toward truly making a difference.

Getting time off is no problem. The scheduling is really flexible, which is important as a college student. The Director and Assistant Director are super understanding of any need that may arise. I threw my heart and soul into this job and got infinitely more back in return.
cons:
As a consultant, I see zero cons whatsoever. Sometimes, the number of hours available vary between semesters, but the Director and Assistant Director are really amazing about clearly communicating what they can offer. 

As a Coordinator, there are a few more downsides. The leadership team structure has been in flux for a little while-- and it's always changing a little bit, due to the fact that people graduate and leave fairly often. This can occasionally result in unclear expectations from the Director and Assistant Director, and it can be tricky to communicate effectively with everyone on your committee. But when emotions at work get messy, the Director and Assistant Director are well-equipped to handle it; they clearly view you as a person first and an employee second, and that to me is worth more than any frustration that might arise.

review_title: Great environment, great people, crippling bureaucracy, out of touch leadership
pros: There's a lot of talent on the campus and some very important and interesting work being done.
cons:
State cuts to education have made money scarce.  Anything that brings in money is fairly safe (research).  Anything that doesn't, will get squeezed (anything student related).

IU/IUPUI is a huge bureaucracy with deep political divisions.  If you're hired into a group that's along one of those fault lines or which has become a political football, it can be a miserable experience working there.  

In the bigger divisions, those working with the students or in daily operations are prevented from making strategic decisions through official channels due to the crippling bureaucracy around them.  The only people able to initiate meaningful change are so high up in the organization that they're isolated from daily operations and student life.  So change happens in secret or out of nowhere from well-intentioned, but often, out of touch leadership.  

Many divisions that face and support the students are treated as a necessary evil that's drawing valuable resources away from research.

pros: There are only a few teachers and other faculty members who I can count on one hand that are mindful in my opinion, and worried about the future of their prospective students and other faculty from all backgrounds.
cons: Beware for this school can be highly discriminative, although this schools screams diversity. There is a lack of minority students in their programs, although I come across lots of smart minority students, who makes the grades. Also if you are a minority, and experience injustice with any faculty member, a problem of this sort will not be looked into and sides will unjustly be taken. I have witnessed unfairity in all directions as a faculty member. I am fair, and don't believe in taking sides which sets me apart from other people who I work with on a daily basis.It is also funny how some of the top professionals over this school are uncaring about this situation. It's hard trying to work and fit in with an environment, where it hurts to see other people be treated so wrongly. It is also hard trying to cope with faculty getting away with treating other faculty so wrongly. The pay is okay but for what it is worth I would have another job by now if it was not for the economy.

job_title: Übersetzer / Redakteur für Englisch in Indianapolis, IN
pros: They are very willing to work with my schedule as a student, and apparently are willing to do the same for full time staff. I was given the opportunity to learn as much in my position that someone would in the position for a small city. There are plentiful duties, but no real stress was felt for getting most things done. Plenty of down time to be able to learn via tutorials while on the clock. Much better pay than minimum wage (11.25/hr).
cons: No possibility for full time as a student. No holiday pay, no sick pay, no vacation pay. No possibility to work weekends (which could be a pro but not for a full course load when you need the money/hours).

pros: People at IUPUI are nice.  The school provides great technology for getting work done.  There is a sincere commitment to providing a great education and research opportunities for students.
cons: Many of the reviews for IUPUI state that it is very flexible and low pressure.  This is great for people who just want a job, rather than a career.  If you are career oriented and want to grow, the glacial pace at which things move can be very frustrating.  There are a million hoops to jump through to get anything done at the university level.  Pay is well below market rates.  In the school in which I work, there is a definite class system and staff are treated as inferior to faculty.

job_title: Studnet Service Coordinator in Indianapolis, IN

(only be careful about excepting trying to many things which might be added into your job description with no hopes of compensation)

The pay scale is very off and you could find yourself stuck in a job making minimal increases despite the fluctuating work load.

pros: I liked alot of my coworkers and my immediate supervisor.  the Job wasnt too hard and usually gave me time to study. The lunch breaks were great but spoiled me a little for other jobs. There are always opportunities to get more hours if you needed them.   it was a fine experience.
cons: The senior management wasted too much time and made things more difficult for those under them.   They were also extremely sneaky as with a plans to phase employees out in place of ticket machines while maintaining that they weren't

review_title: Perspective of a Graduate Researcher in Earth Sciences
pros: The scientists that I worked with and learned from are world class, as is the research. Lab facilities are very good, competitive skills are taught with a focus on up-to-date field techniques that left me feeling competitive in today's job market.
cons: Classes could be better organized to maximize learning and subject coverage. Professors might work together more often to create cross-disciplinary research. Department feels fragmented at times, some group activities/bbqs etc to create a more convivial atmosphere could pay great dividends.

review_title: Excellent environment, great retirement benefits, wonderful people!
pros: I was a staff employee and pay wasn't great, but the benefits were excellent. Time off is generous plus IUPUI contributes 10% of one's salary to a retirement account each year (no match required; 3 year vesting period.)  Overall, I liked the atmosphere and the people.
cons: Within my school, there was a lack of communication.  Although I liked working independently, many times I wanted there to be more of a team effort.  I put in long hours -- sometimes up to 60 a week -- to get all of my work finished.  As is common these days, there is more to do with less resources.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Indianapolis, IN
pros: As an Undergraduate Research Assistant I was allowed to select my hours. Dr. Watson was pleasant to work and talk with. It was not a very demanding job and most of my general work was spent cleaning and sterilizing lab equipment. After a few months of doing that and observing the graduate students, Dr. Watson said I may be asked to begin helping them with their experiments.
cons: The commute took valuable study time away from me. The reason for this being that I would often work after I had finished my classes for the day. The traffic in Indianapolis usually would get very heavy by the the time I finished work and I had a heavy study schedule.

review_title: Decent on campus job for students passionate about writing
job_title: Writing Center Consultant in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The coworkers are undoubtedly the best part of the job--all are intelligent, vibrant, and compassionate people. Since both UWC locations are on campus, it's ideal for a full time student who has a few hours between classes and wants to work. You will also meet an amazing variety of international students and students from pretty much every socioeconomic background.
cons: Your wage pretty much stays the same. It's not the fault of the immediate superior but is rather simply the way the university is structured. Stagnant wage is one thing, but the wage itself is incredibly low for the type of work. Private tutors can easily make double, triple, or even quadruple what the UWC pays.

review_title: IUPUI offers great opportunities to learn real world skills.
pros: Student internships allow for experience in real-life situations and training for future jobs.  The environment is not high stress and everything applies toward what you will be doing in the real world.  The staff is friendly and helpful.
cons: The internship position is generally unpaid with the school (it does count as a class) and requires two full weekend days even if  you are a full time student.  The equipment is older, but is getting better each new semester.

review_title: Great place to work - very laid back and encouraging.
pros: Very flexible schedule, no work pressure.  This is way better than working in the corporate world with all the pressure from managers.  Great place to do research.  I'm able to have lots of free time during the day while and time off when I need / want it.  overall awesome
cons: The pay is low.  $11.00 an hour so it's hard to make a living here.  But the freedom is worth the trade - as long as you live with someone else who can pay the bills.

review_title: Great Benefits, but Culture Leads to Stagnation
job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The benefits at IUPUI are amazing, and very inexpensive. Staff members tend to stay for a long time. 30+ years is not uncommon. The pace of work is often leisurely. Most positions offer good work-life balance.
cons: Low pay compared to private sector. It is nearly impossible to get a raise above the standard 2-3% unless you leave the university and apply for a different job and get rehired. The culture of permanence can lead employees to get far too comfortable in their positions, and job performance suffers because of it.

pros: Indiana University has a great working environment,fantastic insurance/benefits/pay, good experience opportunities.
cons: Parking (costs and location) and needs better opportunities for advancement. I have some trouble sitting at a desk all throughout the day. Also, some issues with management working effectively to promote effective working environment. One of my collegues is able to not work effectively, calls in many days per week; and the department is unable to discipline due to many of the organizations put in place for accomodations/descrimination . Makes for a stressful environment.

pros: Working at IUPUI has been a blessing for advancing my career. The educational opportunities I've been afforded here cant be found just anywhere, especially Indianapolis. I've been promoted twice since starting here 7 years ago. I also feel stable in an educational environment that's in growth mode.
cons: I do wish the pay was a little more competitive. Friends of mine in the private sector seem to be doing much better, even though it's the same job. This may be countered, however, with the fact that benefits at IUPUI are so good.

review_title: Nearly Useless degree. Faculty is not interested in you getting a job.
pros: Easy campus to reach. Close to home in you live in Indianapolis
cons: Everything else you can think of. The cost is not bad, but you literally have no opportunities to recoup your cost with a job after graduation. I'm completing my M.S. in chemistry this fall with a 3.4 gpa and my best prospect in Allison Transmission warehouse worker. Recruitment office did their best to get me hired installing heating and cooling systems (with a degree in chemistry) but could not. What's that tell you?

pros: Very supportive staff that is willing to help direct you to who/where you need (I.e.-thesis form sign offs, class registration, etc). Laid back and friendly environment. Empathetic of personal emergencies that may conflict with work.
cons: Horrible communication between departments (I.e.-with the Graduate Student Office), multiple staff members have different answers to the same administrative question; paucity of TAs in the department due to increasing attrition rates among the phD students makes it hard to find someone to cover your class if there is a personal emergency.

job_title: Preschool Assistant Teacher in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Very sweet kids, one or two kind employees
cons:
I can only think of a few employees I had good experiences with here. Mostly, there was gossip and hatred amongst all the employees toward each other and management.

Most of the employees are college students who are getting their degree in education. There isn't really a deep care and compassion for the kids. It seems like most of the people were just wanting to get through the day. I saw children yelled at, put in inappropriate restraints and treated with contempt when they dropped something, had an accident or were tired/cranky.

pros: excellent PTO program, employer sponsored pension plan and matching 401k, reasonably priced medical plans (and many to choose from), tuition deferrals for employees
cons: Very outdated computer technology and support, lots of red tape preventing efficiency in many departments, lack of concern about employee development or retention, little sensed of ownership among employees and management, many managers have little or no training in management and management skills are not developed or emphasized.

pros: Excellent benefits, expanding in size and staff, hard to be fired.
cons: $50 a month for parking, work quality depends on who you work with, no opportunity for advancement, HR is not concerned about you, higher ups always in competition with each other and will attack others.

pros: The research facilities and resources that are available to postdocs are good. The compensation is on par with market rate, plus the benefits and overall environment are nice. Good work-life balance and flexibility.
cons: Employment status as a postdoc means you are considered somewhere between "staff" and "faculty". You get some of the perks from it, such as more generous vacation time, but your funding (and thus salary) is directly tied to the PI's budget. There is no protection or supplement by IUPUI in the event that funding runs out prior to the agreed upon length of your appointment.

pros: Good pay, good hours, great benefits, great people. Best job I have ever and. There are no complaints. You'll get to learn a lot and have fun while doing it, while impacting lives in a positive way.
cons: It has nothing to do with the actual job, but be prepared to have the occasional struggle with finding a parking space if you get in too late, and the ongoing construction around the area can make traffic a pain sometimes.

pros: Good insurance and PTO.  Great location.  Lots of activities for employees.  If you are interested in completing/continuing your education, the tuition benefits are great.  Insurance costs are very low and coverage is still very good.
cons: Very small (if any) raises in last 5 years.  Little promotion from within.  Systems are cumbersome to learn and to use.  Employee morale seems to being sinking and we are losing more and more people to jobs outside of the university.

review_title: Math Assistance Center: Best student job on campus!
pros: Excellent management, fun working environment, challenging and rewarding.  Pay is good and work is easy if you are comfortable with math and interacting with students.
cons: Some employees not as helpful as they should be, leaving more work for other people.  Some policies are overbearing, such as no phone usage or technology at tables.

pros: Many opportunities to learn with education benifit
cons: Research associate is considered as Academic, but with not much rights. No definite vacation time other than what your principal investigator allows. Working days, nights, weekends, Xmas and new year days (like a slave) with low pay. They eliminate your job when grant money runs out, but, will not give you RIF status to help you reemploy with IUPUI.

review_title: Great Place to work, great team enviroment
pros: If you want to further your education or skills, a university is a great place to work. Tuition assistance and trainings are always available.  I truly enjoyed working here. Everyone is friendly and helpful. There were always fun events to attend. They are always working to improve employee satisfaction.
cons: Sometimes the workload is large and it can be difficult to take off due to the fact that there is not coverage available. So, if you go on vacation, all of your work is there when you get back.

pros: Great benefits, and a relaxed atmosphere.  I can't emphasize enough the benefits.  30 days of vacation is unheard of when you start a professional position.  There is also some flexibility in schedule, but most folks work their 40 hours and go home.

review_title: Depends on where you are, I guess...

cons: The environment was highly-politicized and the salary disparity between those in the sciences and those in the arts was gross. There was definitely a feeling that everyone is easily replaceable. But, I'd guess that's not true in each school/department. There was a lot of duplicitousness the couple years I was there.

job_title: Financial Services Coordinator in Indianapolis, IN
pros: It was the golden handcuffs.  Benefits and time off were outstanding.  Tuition discounts were available to staff.
cons: Management was clueless.  All they did was waste money and make life miserable for employees on a daily basis.  My boss was the devil.  She seemed to delight in making my life horrible.  It was next to impossible to transfer to another position.  After literally 20+ interviews and no offers, I decided to seek employment off campus.  Basically one person was in charge of most all of the activities on campus: hiring, financial, etc. She had way too much power and control over everything.

review_title: IUPUI Is run like a business not a university

review_title: Enriching and absolute if you are committed to professional development.

cons: Salaries are below the market valuation in For-Profit atmospheres. The change for advancement can be limited.

pros: Great learning experience. Opportunity to work with multiple disciplines. Good for people who wish to pursue a career in academia. Chance to publish at lots of conferences and journals.
cons: Projects and work dependent on funding from various sources. Package may be a little lesser than industry but that is the case with academia.

cons: Limited opportunities for advancement and for salary increases.  All times of year are busy.

pros: I have received awesome training and support from my superiors.
cons: No benefits as a part time employee.  IF you want to become full time you are in very competitive environment.  It is difficult to get an opportunity to even do clerical work with a MA. Also Those who are in a position that is classified as  a clerical you cannot teach as well.

cons:
Pay levels are terrible if you don't have a PhD.
Research technicians can be at mercy of departmental squabbles and turf wars.
Often funded by soft money, some instability.

pros: The money is great. Simple job. Pretty relaxed. Understanding if something comes up and you have to come in late. Self paced training.
cons: Boring. Unbelievably so. Very short staffed. At times it seems like they dont care and just want you take calls without breaks between them. Can feel depressing at times because everyone stays in their own cubicle.

pros: I worked at IUPUI in athletics while finishing my senior year of college. IUPUI was not only a great school, but also a great place to work. I developed friendships and still keep in touch with my mentors.
cons: When you calculate how much I got paid per hour (I accepted tuition reimbursement) it was very low. But I was happy to not have to pay for most of tuition that semester!

pros: Still good to great  (although declining) benefits, entry level salaries okay (but be aware it is hard to get raises, they only way it is to hop from position to position)

review_title: Lots of freedom - creativity was encouraged.
pros: I had a very positive experience - mostly because my students were interested in succeeding and applied themselves.
